question: Hey, boy! What you doin' with my mama's car? Wait there! Ain't you ashamed? Tryin' to steal an old lady's automobile.
answer: I been thinkin' about buyin' me one.

question: Bull. You ain't got money for dinner, let alone buy no car.
answer: Now I got enough money for cokes, and since it don't look like you're gonna invite me inside--

question: You'd steal the dining room table if I did.
answer: Come to town with me, then. How'd that be?

question: Goin' to work anyway.
answer: Goin' to work, huh? What do you do?

question: None of your business.
answer: I bet you're a...movie star! No...A lady mechanic?...No...A maid?--

question: What do you think I am?
answer: A waitress.

question: What line of work are you in? When you're not stealin' cars?
answer: I tell you, I'm lookin' for suitable employment right at the moment.

question: What did you do before?
answer: I was in State Prison.

question: State Prison?
answer: Yeah.

question: Guess some little old lady wasn't so nice.
answer: It was armed robbery.

question: My, my, the things that turn up in the driveway these days.
answer: What do y'all do for a good time around here, listen to the grass grow?

question: Guess you had a lot more fun up at State Prison, huh?
answer: See this foot? I chopped two toes off of it. With an axe.

question: What? Why?
answer: To get off the damn work detail, that's why. Want to see?

question: No!... I surely don't intend to stand here and look at your dirty feet in the middle of Main Street. Boy, did you really do that?
answer: Yeah.

question: You must be crazy. What's it like?
answer: Prison?

question: No, armed robbery.
answer: It's...I don't know...it isn't like anything.

question: Hah! I knew you never robbed bo place, you faker.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: Yeah, well you got one all right, I guess...but you wouldn't have the gumption to use it.
answer: You just keep your eyes open.

question: Hey, what's your name, anyway?
answer: Clyde Barrow.

question: Hi, I'm Bonnie Parker. Please to meet you. ...You ready?...
answer: ...Hey, wait...

question: Aren't you ready? Well, get ready! C'mon, honey, c'mon, boy...let's go...let's...
answer: Hey...hey, wait a minute...quit that now, cut it out. I said, cut it out! Look, I don't do that. It's not that I can't-- --it's just that I don't see no percentage in it. I mean there's nothin' wrong with me, I don't like boys.

question: Boy...boy...boy...
answer: Boy, what?

question: Your advertising is dandy. Folks'd just never guess you don't have a thing to sell. You better take me home, now.
answer: Wait!

question: Don't touch me!
answer: If all you want's stud service, then get on back to West Dallas and stay there the rest of your life! But you're worth more'n that, a lot more, and you know it, and that's why you come along with me. You could find a lover boy on every corner in town and it doesn't make a damn to them whether you're waiting on tables or picking cotton, so long as you cooperate. But it does make a damn to me!

question: Why?
answer: Why? Because you're different! You're like me and you want different things. You and me travelin' together, we could cut clean acrost this state, and Kansas, too, and maybe dip into Oklahoma, and Missouri or whatnot, and catch ourselves highpockets and a highheeled ol' time. We can be somethin' we could never be alone. I'll show you...when we walk into the Adolphus Hotel in San Antone', you wearin' a silk dress, they'll be waitin' on you and believe me, sugar, they're gonna know your last name.

question: When'd you figure that all out?
answer: First time I saw you.

question: How come?
answer: 'Cause you may be the best damn girl in Texas.

question: Who are you, anyway?
answer: I'll tell you about you. Lessee...You were born somewheres around East Texas...got a big old family, right?...You went to school, of course, but you didn't take to it much 'cause you was a lot smarter than everybody else anyway. So you just quit. Now... ...When you were sixteen...no, seventeen, there was a guy who worked in...uh...

question: Cement plant--
answer: Right. Cement plant. And you liked him 'cause he thought you was just as nice as you could be. You almost married that guy, but then...you thought, no, you didn't think you would. So you got your job in the cafe... And every morning you wake up and you hate it. You just hate it. And you get down there and you put on your white uniform--

question: Pink.
answer: And the truck drivers come in to eat greasy burgers and they kid you and you kid them back, but they're stupid and dumb, boys with big tattoos all over 'em, and you don't like it...And they ask you for dates and sometimes you go...but you mostly don't, and all they ever try is to get into your pants whether you want to or not...and you go home and sit in your room and think, when and how will I ever get away from this?...And now you know. Change that. I don't like it. God, you're a knockout.

question: Hey, that ain't ours.
answer: Sure it is.

question: But we came in this one.
answer: Don't mean we have to go home in it.

question: Clyde... Clyde...
answer: Hey, lady.

question: Where you been keeping yourself?
answer: Slept out by the car.

question: Oh...These accommodations ain't particularly deluxe.
answer: No...If they're after us, I want the first shot. Come on, you got some work to do.

question: You're good.
answer: The best.

question: And modest...
answer: Come on. Got you all set up over here. Set her spinnin'. Again. Come down slow with it... Ain't you something? I tell you I'm going to get you a Smith and Wesson, it'll be easier in your hand. Now try it again once...

question: Miss Bonnie Parker. And I'm Clyde Barrow. We rob banks. You just stay in the car and watch and be ready. Okay now? You just be ready if I need you. Scared?
answer: No.

question: What are you thinkin' about?
answer: Nothin'. What are you waitin' for?

question: This is a stickup. Just take it easy and nothin' will happen to you. Gimme the money.
answer: Heighdy.

question: Gimme the money!
answer: What money? There ain't no money here, mister.

question: What do you mean there ain't no money? This here is a bank, ain't it?
answer: This was a bank. We failed three weeks ago.

question: What? What?? Tell her! Tell her!
answer: As I was tellin' this gentleman, our bank failed last month and ain't no money in it. I sure am sorry.

question: We got $1.98 and you're laughin'. Keep it running. Give me a loaf of bread, a dozen eggs and a quart of milk. This is a stickup. I'll take all the money in that drawer now. Get the hell out of here! Damn him, that big son of a bitch... He tried to kill me... I ain't got eyes in back of my head... I didn't want to hurt him. It wasn't a real robbery... Some food and a little bit of dough. I'm not against him. Damn! What was wrong, anyway? You just blowed it away.
answer: Well...I'm not sure... Say, them little red things there stickin' up? Are they gas pumps? Isn't that interesting? How does that there gasoline get in my little old car? My, you're a smart fellow. You sure know a lot about automobiles, don't you? Well, would you know what kind of a car this is? No, no. No, this is a stolen Chevrolet 8- cylinder coupe.

question: You ain't scared, are you? I believe he is. What a pity. We sure coulda used a smart boy who knows such a great deal about automobiles. You a good driver, boy? No, I don't think so. He's better off here...
answer: What's your name, boy? What's the C.W. for? I'm Miss Bonnie Parker and this is Mr. Clyde Barrow. We... rob... banks.

question: Ain't nothing wrong with that, is there, boy?
answer: No, he ain't the one.

question: Unless, Boy, you think you got enough guts for our line of work?
answer: Oh, a man with a record!

question: Now look here, I know you got the nerve to short-change old ladies who come in for gas, but what I'm askin' you is have you got what it takes to pull bank jobs with us?
answer: Mr. C.W. Moss?

question: Prove it.
answer: C.W., what are you doing? Why do you do that? It's just disgusting, that's why. But...but it makes everything sweet! Clyde, why does he have to stay in the same room as us?

question: Lemme show you about tomorrow.
answer: Why?

question: Now C.W.'ll be waitin' right outside in the car. Here is the teller's cage. Four of them and over here the desks and what have you...
answer: Why, Clyde...

question: Hmmm??
answer: In the same room with us?

question: Hell, where else? Ain't gonna spread out all over the state... Not yet, anyway. Now, the door to the bank is here now. You cover me from there.
answer: Just that I love you so much.

question: Boy, you gotta be poor in the head. You...! Count of you I killed a man. Murder...you too. Dumb ass stupid. Ever do a dumb thing like that again, I'll kill you boy!
answer: Ssshh! If you boys want to talk why don't you go outside? What do you think of me, C.W.? Why'nt you come get it? Whyn't you come get it, C.W.? All right, I'll bring it myself. You simpleton, what would you do if we just pulled out some night while you was asleep? That's right, C.W. We'll always be around to take care of you.

question: Bonnie, I want to talk to you. Sit down. This afternoon we killed a man and we were seen. Now nobody knows who you are yet, but they're going to be after me and anybody who's runnin' with me. Now that's murder now and it's gonna get rough. Look, I can't get out, but right now you still can. You say the word and I'll put you on the bus to go back to your Mother. 'Cause you mean a lot to me, honey, and I ain't going to make you run with me. So if you want, you say the word. Why? We ain't gonna have a minute's peace.
answer: Oh, pshaw.

question: Bonnie, we could get killed.
answer: Who'd wanna kill a sweet young thing like me?

question: I ain't no sweet young thing.
answer: Oh, Clyde, I can't picture you with a halo, and if you went to the other place you'd rob the Devil blind, so he'd kick you right back to me.

question: "What a beautiful thought I am thinking Concernin' that great speckled bird, Remember his name is recorded on the pages of God's Holy word..."
answer: All right, now you did foolish things as a young man, honey-love, but you went and paid your debt to society and that was right. But now you just gettin' back in with the criminal element.

question: Criminal element! This is my brother, darlin'. Shoot, he ain't no more criminal than you are, Blanche.
answer: Well, that ain't what I heard.

question: Now word of mouth just don't go, darlin', you gotta have the facts. Shoot. Why he and me growed up together, slept and worked side by side. God, what a boy he was!
answer: He's a crook.

question: Now you stop bad-mouthin' him, Blanche. We're just gonna have us a little family visit for a few weeks and then we'll go back to Dallas and I'll get me a job somewheres. I just ain't gonna work in your Daddy's church--That's final. "What a beautiful thought I am thinking Concernin' that great speckled bird..."
answer: Buck!

question: Clyde! You son of a bitch!
answer: How's ma? How's sister?

question: Just fine, just fine. Send their best to you.
answer: Hey, you're fillin' out there. Must be that prison food.

question: Hey, brother, let's you and me do a little talkin'.
answer: Here, C.W., take the girls' picture.

question: It was you or him, wasn't it?
answer: Huh?

question: That guy you killed. You had to, didn't ya?
answer: Yeah, he put me in a spot, so I had to. He didn't have a Chinaman's chance.

question: But you had to--
answer: Yeah. I had to.

question: Don't say nothin' to Blanche about it.
answer: Hey, that time you broke out of jail, she talk you into goin' back?

question: Yeah, you hear about that?
answer: I won't say nothin' to Bonnie about it.

question: I appreciate it.
answer: Yeah...say, what d'ya think of Bonnie?

question: She's a real peach. Boy, are we gonna have us a good time!
answer: We surely are!

question: Yessir! What are we gonna do?
answer: Well, how's this--I thought we'd all go to Missouri. They ain't lookin' for me there. We'll hole up someplace and have us a regular vacation. All right?

question: No trouble, now?
answer: No trouble. I ain't lookin' to go back to prison.

question: Hey, what's this I hear about you cuttin' up your toes, boy?
answer: That ain't but half of it. I did it so I could get off work detail-- breakin' those damned rocks with a hammer day and night. Sure enough, next week I got paroled. I walked out of that god-forsaken jail on crutches.

question: Shoot--
answer: Ain't life grand?

question: And the doc, he takes him aside, says, "Son, your old mama just gettin' weak and sickly layin' there. I want you to persuade her to take a little Brandy, y'know, to pick her spirits up." "Why, doc," he says, "you know my mamma is a teetotaler. She wouldn't touch a drop." "Well, I tell you what," the doc says, "why don't you bring her a fresh quart of milk every day from your farm, 'cept you fix it up so half of it's Brandy and don't let on!" So he does that, doctors it up with Brandy, and his mamma drinks some of it. And the next day he brings it again and she drinks some more--and she keeps it up every day. Finally, one week later, he brings her the milk and don't you know she just shallows it all down, and looks at her bag and says, "Son, whatever you do, don't sell that cow!" I give him a month's rent in advance. We're all set. Let's get inside.
answer: Pull up and unload the stuff.

question: Honey-love, I'm taking you into our first home.
answer: Oh look, it's so clean, Buck. And a Frigidaire...not an icebox!

question: He give me the grocery number. Lemme see, eh 4337...Operator... please ma'm, may I have 4337...if you please?
answer: Oh...they got linoleum on the counter. Ain't that clever!

question: Hello, Smitty's grocery...I'd like to order a mess of groceries. Oh yeah...eh 143 Hillsdale Street. Lessee, about 8 pounds of porkchops, 4 pounds of red beans...a can of Chase and Sandborn...uh.
answer: Oh, isn't this something, Daddy!

question: Sshh. Uh...quart of milk...uh 8 bottles of Dr. Pepper and that's it, I guess. No...no. Uh...a box of Rice Krispies...Bye now.
answer: My, you need a haircut, Daddy. You look like a hillbilly boy.

question: Gotcha! Boy, you ain't never gonna beat me but you keep tryin' now.
answer: Jest like an ol' man. Plays checkers all the time and doesn't pay any attention to his poor lonely wife.

question: Oh, Daddy, you shore need a haircut. You look just like a little old hillbilly boy, I do declare. Oh mercy me, oh my stars! Oh, Daddy! Yore such a slowpoke!
answer: Hush up a little. They're in the next room.

question: Shoot, there's always somebody in this room, the next room and ever' other kind of room.
answer: Oof!...now that ain't no nice way to talk about my brother.

question: I ain't talking about your brother. Honey, do you ever just want to be alone with Me? I don't just mean like that...I mean do you ever have the notion of us bein' out together and alone, like at some fancy ball, or, I don't know, where we walk in all dressed and they announce us and it's fancy and in public, but we're alone somehow. We're separate from everybody else, and they know it.
answer: I always feel like we're separate from everybody else.

question: Buck, don't let that woman talk to me like that!
answer: You shouldn't have done it, Blanche. It was a dumb thing to do.

question: Please, Buck, I didn't marry you to see you shot up! Please, let's go! Let's get out of here and leave. Make him stop the car and let us out!
answer: Can't. I killed a man. We're in this now.

question: Shut up! Just shut up your big mouth! At least do that, will ya, just shut up.
answer: Cut it out, Bonnie.

question: Stop the car. I want to talk to you.
answer: What is it?

question: Get rid of her.
answer: Can't do that. She's Buck's wife.

question: Get rid of both of them then.
answer: Why? What's the matter with you anyway?

question: She's what's the matter with me, a damn stupid back country hick without a brain in her head. She ain't nothin' but prunes and proverbs.
answer: What makes you any better? What makes you so damn special? You're just a West Dallas waitress who spent half your time pickin' up truck drivers!

question: You talk to me like that! Big Clyde Barrow, just the same as your brother, an ignorant uneducated hillbilly. Only special thing about you is your peculiar ideas about lovemakin'--which is no love makin' at all.
answer: Look, Bonnie--

question: Clyde...honey...I didn't mean all that, honey. Blame it on all that shootin', I just felt so bad...sure enough...Clyde?
answer: Okay...Okay, hon...let's get movin'...

question: Hey now, here's something! Listen here When he saw several machine guns in the car he was certain he'd caught Clyde Barrow, Bonnie Parker, and maybe Buck Barrow and the third unidentified member of the gang. It took a lot of telephoning and explaining to convince the motorcycle cop that his captives were two highway patrolmen and a blonde-haired stenographer from the Highway Patrol--. Haw! Haw! Anderson was held up as an example for every other Texas peace officer today. "That was a mighty brave thing," explained Highway Patrol Chief L.C. Winston.
answer: Sheriff!

question: Sweet Jesus, I never seen shootin' like that!
answer: Well, now, getta load of this. I want y'all to know we are in the custody of Cap'n Frank Bryce, and Frank here is a Texas Ranger.

question: Say there, peacemaker. I believe you got your spurs all tangled up. You're in Missouri, you know that?
answer: You didn't know you was in Missouri? --he ain't lost...them banks are offerin' extra reward money fer us, and Frank figured on easy pickin's, didn't you? Didn't you? --Now you ain't hardly doin' your job, Texas Ranger. You oughta be home lookin' after the rights of poor folks, not out chasin' after us.

question: Easy there, Clyde. Why take is so personal.
answer: Reg'lar laws is one thing. But this here bounty hunting, we got to discourage that.

question: Buck, get the Kodak!
answer: Hot dog!

question: We're mighty proud to have a Texas Ranger in the family.
answer: ...keep him set on the hood, there...more to the sun, like that...yeah...when all his ranger friends see this...I bet he's gonna wish he was dead!

question: ...see what come o' your mischief?...not doin' your job? Down in Duncanville last year poor farmers kepts the laws away from us with shot guns...you're s'posed to be protectin' them from us, and they're protectin' us from you. --don't make sense, do it?
answer: C'mon, now, Clyde, you and Bonnie first. Move into him, right close, right friendly.

question: ...yeah, yeah...quick, Buck, get it...
answer: ...I'm gettin' it, I'm gettin' it. I got the picture. I got the picture...

question: Lemme be, lemme be...
answer: I got the PICTURE!

question: ...All right, all right... WE GOT YOU...HEAR?... REMEMBER... This is the Barrow gang. Everybody just take it easy and nobody will get hurt.
answer: Don't do nothin' silly now.

question: Okay, relax. We're in Oklahoma now. Slow down. Hell. That ain't much, is it?
answer: Times is hard,

question: Well, let's get to it. This is Clyde Barrow. Buck Barrow... Bonnie Parker...C.W. Clyde, Buck...Bonnie...C.W. Clyde, Clyde again...Buck...Bonnie...C.W. Bonnie...C.S....Clyde...
answer: Um...eh...Clyde?

question: Hah?
answer: Uh, Clyde...well...what about Blanche?

question: She'll be doin' right well to spend it at all.
answer: Bonnie? Look, Bonnie, I've said it and I guess I'll keep sayin' it before we're thru--Blanche is Buck's wife and Buck is family.

question: --she's such a silly-Billy... My family could use some of that money.
answer: Them laws have been hangin' round your mamas house 'til all hours, Bonnie. It's just too risky to go there.

question: Well, where can we go? We rob the damn banks, what else do we do?
answer: I hear you, C.W.

question: I'll tear 'em apart! Those punks! Steal a man's car right out from under him! Wait till I get my hands on those kids, Velma, I'll show 'em!
answer: What if they have guns, Eugene?

question: We'd better get the police and let them handle this.
answer: Right.

question: ...see anythin', Buck?
answer: --not yet, boy.

question: --and nobody saw her leave, or heard anythin' ...C.W....? ...Well, where do you think she could've gone?...Buck?...Buck?
answer: Jesus, I don't know...

question: There! There! There!
answer: Leave me alone! Leave me alone!

question: Hey...hey, hey, baby, hey, Bonnie, hey baby... ...Hey, hey now...just where did you think you were goin'?... --Huh. Bonnie? Where? Where?
answer: I don't know! You're hurting me, I was just scared is all...and my mama's been on my mind, and she's gettin' so old...

question: Boy, don't ever leave without sayin' somethin'. You really scared me, Bonnie.
answer: But I mean it, though. I want to see my mama. Please, Clyde.

question: I hate you all.
answer: I hate y'all, too.

question: no, I really hate you. Oh, baby, I've got the blues so bad...
answer: Bonnie?...is it your mama, what your mama said?

question: What mama?...she's just an old woman now...I have no mama... ...so funny...I thought when we first went out, we were really goin' somewhere...but this is it-- we're just goin', huh?
answer: Do you care about where we're goin'?

question: Not as long as you care about me.
answer: Why I love you, sugar. --wherever.

question: Lie down now, honey.
answer: I've done enough!

question: You have to lie down...it's the only way we can tell what we'll look kike together.
answer: Whatta you think?

question: That's not the right tie!
answer: What?

question: You can't wear polka-dots on an occasion like this.
answer: Well what--

question: Stripes. Don't go away now. Perfect.
answer: OK, o.k. If we're gonna do this, at least I can tie it myself. Lie down before you fall down. Better?

question: Much. All right, shut your eyes now.
answer: No, you first.

question: One for the money.
answer: Two for the show.

question: Three to get ready--
answer: The men are on the other side. Oh, God, please help us! Dear Father in Heaven, get us out of this and Buck will never do another bad thing in his life! My eyes! God, I think I'm blind. ...light hurts so bad... Please, please get us to a doctor! Tell Clyde to get us to a doctor. We'll die here.

question: --here, hon'.
answer: Clyde, Clyde, please get us to a doctor. He's your brother!

question: I was in the bunch that took 'er. See here? Can you make me out? Here I am, see here, right behind Joe Boyd here.
answer: Sure enough, Billy, is that your head there?

question: Still can't figure how we let them other two get away.
answer: Yeah, seems as how nobody can get 'em somehow.

question: Yeah...well, maybe this boy'll be the one to do it, this Hamer guy. Boy if he can't do it, Sheriff, ain't nobody but the whole U.S. Army can do it.
answer: You hear he quit the Rangers on account of Texas got that woman governor. Said he wouldn't work under no woman.

question: Yeah, that's somethin' all right. Say, how many they say he shot anyway in his day?
answer: Sixty-five they say.

question: Blanche Barrow.
answer: What? What? Who is it?

question: You know your husband's dead.
answer: I know.

question: You're going to prison.
answer: I know it.

question: Where's the rest of 'em?
answer: I don't know.

question: Where's the rest of 'em?
answer: I just don't know. I don't know.

question: How'd you get in with them?
answer: I didn't mean to. I didn't. Buck said we was just goin' to visit, we wouldn't be doin' no robbin' and stealin', and then we went to Joplin and all of a sudden they started shootin'. And we run off, God, I was scared. And then it was run all the time, and I wanted to go, I begged to go, but Clyde and Bonnie and C.W.--

question: C.W. C.W. who?
answer: C.W. Moss.

question: Want a ginger-snap, Bonnie?
answer: No, hum-umm. But thanks anyway, Clyde. It's real nice here, just the two of us like this.

question: Uh-huh. Look here, honey, remember this?
answer: Yeah, at the motel.

question: You sure don't resemble that no more. What you writin' this time?
answer: I'm writing a poem about us. I'm writing our story.

question: Oh, are you? Let's hear it. If it's good, I'll mail it in to the Law and it'll be printed in all the papers again.
answer: Just let me finish this line. Okay, here it is. "The Story of Bonnie and Clyde"

question: If they try to act like citizens And rent them a nice little flat About the third night They're invited to fight By a sub-gun's rat-tat-tat.
answer: Damn! That's me! In that poem! A sub-gun's rat-tat-tat! Right in the paper! Jesse James! You hear 'bout old Jesse, now you goin' to hear 'bout Clyde! Pshhhhhh! Damn, Bonnie! You musta been one hell of a waitress! Oooooh, that Clyde! That's my boy, that Clyde! Bonnie... The Poem of Bonnie and Clyde!

question: The Story.
answer: The Story of Bonnie and Clyde! Oh, child, you really did tell that story! Damn!...damn...damn! Hey, listen, Bonnie, how do you feel?

question: Fine.
answer: I mean you feel like you're s'posed to feel after you've uh...

question: Just.
answer: Well, that's good, ain't it. Reason I ask is, I uh... Well, I figger it's a good idea to ask. I mean how else do I tell if I did it the way...

question: Hey. You done just perfect.
answer: I did, didn't I? I mean I did, I really did. I did it, I did, I mean this was my first time and it was just like rollin' off a log when it comes right down to it, it was easy, I mean I didn't even have to try...

question: Bonnie? Bonnie, will you marry me?
answer: How could I do that, Clyde? You know it's impossible. We'd have to go to a Justice of the Peace and the Justice of the Peace is a lawman. We couldn't even take out a license.

question: Hey now, you sound like you been givin' it some thought on your own.
answer: Oh no, I never gave it thought. I haven't thought about it at least ten times a day, I haven't thought about it every minute of my life since I met you.

question: Bonnie...are you crying, honey?
answer: Clyde, why do you want to marry me?

question: To make an honest woman out of you.
answer: Clyde...what would you do, what would you do it some miracle happened and we could walk out tomorrow morning and start all over again, clean, with no record, with nobody after us?

question: Well...I guess I'd do it all different. First off, I wouldn't live in the same state where we pull our jobs. We'd live in one state and stay clean there, and when we wanted to take a bank, we'd go to another state...and... Bonnie? Hey, Bonnie? What happened to C.W.?
answer: He stopped off in that hardware store to get light bulbs for his daddy.

question: Boy, my feet are sweatin'.
answer: You plannin' to drive with your shoes off?

question: Sure, why not? Damn!
answer: You gonna wear 'em?

question: Sure, drive with one eye shut.
answer: Isn't that the prettiest thing, hon? Just look here, you can see every little fingernail on her hands.

question: It is a pretty thing, honey.
answer: We got any peaches? I sure could go for a peach right now.

question: Whyn't we do it tomorrow?
answer: Do what?

question: Tomorrow's Sunday, ain't it? We could drive all night and be on that golf course tomorrow morning!
answer: You sure you feel up to it?

question: Yeah, why not? Where is that boy? He's gone too long.
answer: He'll be here. You take a bite, hon.

question: No, it's takin' too long. What if something happened?
answer: Nothin' happened.
